Posts.Content: Springlakegirl wrote: I am new to these discussion boards, but briefly, I am currently in a remission (NED) for over a year and a half.  I have been taking Zometa for over 2 years now for bone mets.  I was taking it every 4 weeks, but a few months ago I got 3 stress fractures.  One in each femur and one in my tibia!  I was sad about this because I run, and had to take a few months off to heal.  I don't feel like I should be getting fractures all over, even if I am running!  I am sure it is related to taking Zometa, and have reduced it to every 8 weeks.  My oncologist feels strongly that it is important for me to take, and studies show it helps, but I want to be able to run and not feel so breakable!  I am healthy otherwise, and wanting to enjoy this wonderful time of feeling well, but my femurs ache almost all of the time.  I can run a time or two a week on my treadmill, but have to take a lot of Ibuprofen.  Any thoughts?  Have others had problems with fractures while taking Zometa?  Thanks for your help, and I'm looking forward to getting to know some of you through these discussion boards.  I am finally feeling on top of things emotionally so I feel more able to have these types of discussions.  Thank you! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: How often should I take Zometa? Springlakegirl Springlakegirl

Posts.Content: Springlakegirl wrote: This was the radio interview I had on Thursday morning. They didn't edit hardly at all, and I'm no pro at being interviewed, but I feel pretty good about it overall. The woman who interviewed me has an amazing British accent, and I sound like a little girl on the air, I think, but oh well! ;) I guess that's why she is the host! The interview went so quickly, and she wanted me to share my story, and then a message at the end. I'm a little hesitant to share this. I don't think everyone on this board will like it, because I do like to offer hope for those battling stage 4 breast cancer. It's what I was looking for when I was diagnosed, and it's sooo hard to find. There are many more things I would have liked to share in this interview, but all of a sudden, it was just over! If I am ever interviewed again, I have learned from this experience. Anyway, if optimism is annoying to you right now, then don't listen to it, but if that's what you need, I hope it will give you a lift.  I go in for a follow-up PET scan Monday, and will get results Thursday, so hopefully I will be able to continue saying I am NED, or possibly "cured", but until I hear otherwise, I think sharing a positive story about MBC is what I want to do. I don't know all of you, but I truly feel like I love you and want the best for each of you!  This link goes to my online journal, which has the link to the podcast right on it. http://deniseneish.com/journal/ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Radio interview Springlakegirl Bluemnm

Posts.Content: Springlakegirl wrote: 5 years ago today was when I was told my BC had spread to my bones, only 3 weeks after original diagnosis. I am happy to report that I am currently doing very well. I ran 4 miles this morning, coached my son's junior high track team, played 4-square with my younger son, and snuggled and colored with my two girls. (My kids are 13, 7, 7, and 6). I recently had radiation to my one spot of known cancer in my right iliac. My life isn't perfect, and I wish I didn't have to deal with all the cancer crap, but I am happy and healthy overall. I am better able to just live my life without fretting as much as I did at the beginning of all this. These past 5 years have not been easy, but I have also been blessed with a lot of happiness along the way, and I feel very grateful for the many blessings in my wonderful life. I look forward to many healthy years ahead! Best wishes to all you brave women on this site! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Five Years Since Stage 4 Diagnosis Springlakegirl jensgotthis

Posts.Content: Springlakegirl wrote: I posted a new journal entry on my website with a response to Bill Keller's op-ed on metastatic breast cancer patient Lisa Adams.  If you would like to read it go to deniseneish.com and read my latest journal entry. Thanks! :) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: My thoughts on Bill Keller's op-ed Springlakegirl Moderators

Posts.Content: Springlakegirl wrote: I am looking for credible recommendations from people who would know. You ladies!! If you have been to MD Anderson, let me know who you liked? Or who I should avoid. Thanks!! I need to decide this quickly, so I am hoping to get some responses here. Thanks so much again for your help. It really gives me some peace of mind to hear your input and know that I am getting it straight from women who would know! Love you guys!! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Who do you like at MD Anderson? (or dislike?) Springlakegirl Springlakegirl

Posts.Content: Springlakegirl wrote: I spent all last week in Houston at MD Anderson for the first time, for a second opinion after my recent recurrence. I am trying to adjust to a new way of thinking, and I wrote a post on it on my website. It is four pages long, so I will just put a link here:  http://deniseneish.com/journal/ Basically, I am going forward treating my cancer more as "chronic" than terminal, which I know is something many of you do. Although, I must still maintain hope of being cured one day, when the treatment and the time is right. That idea is just helpful for me.  I would love to hear wisdom from any of you on how you view your cancer. Do you feel it is worth risking quality of life for a more intense "curative" approach, or have you moved beyond that, feeling more acceptance of continuously treating cancer throughout your life? And is it helpful for you to hope for a cure one day for yourself, or do you just look it in the eye and face it with as much courage as you can?  I know not everyone is in the same place with treatment, and how much spread you have, etc., so I hope this is not an offensive question for anyone. I just am curious as to how everyone deals with it mentally? I liked my pep talk from Dr. Valero. Maybe it will be helpful for some of you too, so that is why I shared my experience from this last week. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: A change in thinking- and my pep talk from Dr. Valero Springlakegirl

Posts.Content: Springlakegirl wrote: Hey ladies! Just thought I'd check in with you all on this day. It was four years ago today that I was given my stage 4 diagnosis, (only 3 weeks after my original bc diagnosis, which we were still reeling from). I had mets to my spine and pelvis. I don't feel like rehashing it all, but I do feel like sharing positive news, that I am still here, and doing quite well. I was NED for two full years, but had a recurrence last summer. I have one spot in my right iliac, but other than that I am doing great. I am currently on Ibrance (Palbocyclib) + Letrozole (Femara). I also get Zometa every 12 weeks. I am happy about my treatment plan, and feel healthy and strong. My heart is full of love today for all of you, whom I don't even know. I feel connected to you, grateful for you, and hopeful for each one of you to have happiness and many wonderful days ahead. I also plan to be around for many more years writing obnoxiously positive posts on this discussion board, so get used to it! ;) Love and good night to you all! -Denise Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 4 years since stage 4 diagnosis Springlakegirl stagefree

Posts.Content: Springlakegirl wrote: I submitted this op-ed a couple of weeks ago to our local newspaper, but didn't hear back from them, so I posted it on my personal website just yesterday. Then, today, a friend of my husband's told him that he saw my article. Crazy!  They never even notified me that they were going to publish it, but I'm glad that they did!  I don't know if you will all agree with my perspectives or not, but feel free to read it and comment if you want. (you may have to sign in to comment, but I would love any support on there!)  I would love to get more attention on this topic.  I'm not as prolific as Englishmajor or Bestbird, but it made me feel good to get some of my thoughts published about some of the dumb breast cancer messages that are out there. ;) Here is the link:    www.deseretnews.com/article/86...  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: I had an article published! (first time) :) Springlakegirl cookiegal

Posts.Content: Springlakegirl wrote: I found out a couple of days ago that my insurance (Regence Blue Cross Blue Shield) is going to cover Ibrance for me. I was very surprised, because, while I meet most of the requirements to receive this drug, I have had endocrine therapy, and so I assumed I would get denied by insurance, even though my oncologist recommended it for me. I was looking into alternative routes to get access to Ibrance (Palbociclib), but we ran it through insurance first. I think my oncologist did a good job of making the case that it was the right drug for me, and I got approved! I am really happy about this, and wanted to share with any of you who are hoping to get on this drug. I also heard from a friend in Michigan who has MBC who was also approved. She similarly did not know if she would qualify. I don't know what insurance she has, but I think this is promising news. My hospital doesn't have the drug in stock yet, but I should be able to get on it fairly soon. Any other successes with getting insurance approval for Palbociclib out there? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Hope for those wanting to get on Palbociclib (Ibrance) Springlakegirl Moderators

Posts.Content: Springlakegirl wrote: I'm posting a link to an article that gives a lot more optimistic prognosis for those who have "limited" metastatic breast cancer.  Stage 4 breast cancer is a broad category, yet it is all considered the same because the cancer has metastisized, and has therefore spread through the blood and landed somewhere else.  But it still feels to me like there are big differences.  Sometimes it has spread too much to realistically go for a cure.  Other times it has only spread to one or two spots, and that just seems different.   This study shows that there is reason to have hope for a cure if your metastatic breast cancer is limited.  I hesitate to share something that doesn't apply to everyone, but for those who are in this category, I think this is a great find!  I have read this several times when I needed to hear something a little more hopeful.  http://jco.ascopubs.org/content/20/3/620.full.pdf deniseneish.com Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: "Limited" Metastatic Breast Cancer Springlakegirl jhammel
